Slowly at first, then very quickly, I became a fan of Michael Stevens' videos over the last year. They are engaging, full of information, and Michael has incredible energy and charisma, making nerdy, science-y stuff accessible to those who might otherwise find it dry.

After seeing Brain Candy live in Reno, I reluctantly admit I was disappointed. I wasn't sure what it would be, but I expected a little more WOW. Adam Savage has a well-deserved reputation for building cool gadgets and stuff, he's a knowledgeable, likable guy, they both are. But in the end, it was two guys paraphrasing community college physics textbooks and dancing around in between. The crowd loved it, make no mistake--I'm just not sure the rock star status they're trying to connect with really fits. I felt there wasn't much reason to deal with traffic and crowds to see less content than you would find in any randomly picked Vsauce video.

I will look forward to Stevens' future videos and bright career, but I hope any plans for Brain Candy Two include more than just blowing giant smoke rings at the audience with a picture of Bernoulli in the background.

Hey Michael, I have an interesting question that may or may not catch your interest.
Can you eat an alien?

Of course, currently we don't know of any extraterrestrial life forms right now, but let's assume there were. Us humans and other heterotrophs must survive by eating other life forms. Those life forms we eat are made of individual cells, which in turn is made of lipids, carbohydrates, proteins and nucleic acids as well as other organic or inorganic chemicals and trace elements suspended in a bubble of water kept together by a phospholipid bilayer. All the same carbon-based stuff we are made of and that makes sense, we eat those things because they have the same stuff that our body is made of so we can use what we eat to build our bodies or break it down for releasing the energy that keeps our bodies running. However, what would happen when you eat something alien, that may not be made of lipids, proteins, carbohydrates and it's genetics may or may not be based on nucleic acid? Would it even be carbon based? Would it use water as a solvent for it's chemicals or something else? What are the possibilities of what alien life is made off?

Hi Vsause, I know this isn't about the video, but I've been reading up on parallel universes and I've been inspired. Lets say that you can move to another universe via teleportation, if you move to that universe, isn't that technically destroying matter? It would violate the conservation of matter principal since suddenly all your atoms no longer reside in that universe. However, lets say you switch with a bundle of rocks that have the same mass as you. It would still be loss of matter, because those rocks have more electrons, neutrons, and protons. For example, if you took a hydrogen atom (One electron and proton) and switched it with a helium atom (2 electrons, 2 protons, 2 neutrons) Then where did the the extra particles come from?
